title: The Miracle of the Potato
description: I just spent a month in the UK, and potatoes were a part of nearly every meal. But as a food, they almost didn't exist at all.

title: The World's Biggest Comic Strip
description:
Trajan‚Äôs Column is one of the few things I‚Äôve seen in my life that genuinely made me weak in the knees. It's single, continuous marble frieze that tells the story of Rome conquering the Dacian civilization (which was about where modern day Romania is.)  The story is told with hundreds of figures, often stacked five or six layers deep with towns, rivers, ships, and people all happening at once.     

Then you remember this was made around 100 AD. Huge marble blocks lifted, stacked, and then carved after they were in place, a hundred feet in the air, with no modern tools.

And somehow in the 1860s, people managed to take full plaster casts of the entire thing and bring them to London.

@vamuseum

title: Houses Don't Have These Rooms Anymore
description:
Different cultures design homes around their daily rhythms, so the rooms they prioritize change over time! There is one kind of room that was popular in every household from medieval times all the way through the 19th century. 

For amazing still room clips and coverage, go check out @thethymekeeper 

B-Roll taken at Kentwell Hall (@kentwellhall on IG)

Barley Hall and The Fairfax House in York, UK @VisitYork

title: The World's Smallest Micropolice Station
description: Tucked away on a little corner of Trafalgar Square is an assuming little box that holds an impressive record.

title: These Ornaments Don't Exist in the U.S.
description: I was very surprised to learn that even though the Space Race was a massive cultural phenomenon in the 60s and 70s, no major American company made any line of space- themed Christmas ornaments until the 90s.  So if you search on Etsy or Ebay for any vintage 70s space ornaments, they will all be Soviet glass ones.

title: The Only Photo With a Trillion Views
description: There are many famous photographs in the world, but the most-viewed one of all time is WAY OUT in front.

title: Can you eat every continent in one bite?
description: For most of history, all the food you ate was probably grown within walking distance of where you lived. But now with global shipping routes, we can easily access foods from all over the world. But is it possible to make an edible dish from every content (minus Africa) using ingredients than can be found in an average grocery store?

title: A Kid Can Beat You At This Test
description: For a lot of problems, experience really comes in handy. But for certain puzzles, sometimes experience can actually hinder a person's ability to detect a creative solution, as in this test that kids regularly solve faster than adults according to clincial research.

title: Is There A Loophole in The Lottery?
description: Today's lotteries have so many  layers of security- sealed machines, multiple auditors, video surveillance, randomized ball sets, and strict chain-of-custody logs.  But when prizes regularly going over $1B now, you have to wonder how many people would have to collude in order to cheat the current system? 10? 12?

title: How Every Roman Emperor Died
description: Emperor of Rome is not a great job to have.  It's wild that the number who were eliminated by their own guards and soldiers is nearly 40%.

title: Guess What Animal Has The Most Bones?
description: A lot of vertabrates have a surprisingly similar number of bones, despite obvious differences in scale.  For example, the difference between the number of bones in a human and an elephant is pretty small.  However, there is one animal that wins this competition HANDS DOWN.

title: The 40 Hour Work Week is a Scam?
description: Technology keeps getting better and better‚Ä¶ so why doesn‚Äôt this translate into more time off, less stress, or a better quality of life for workers?

title: 3 Crazy Skills Birds Can Learn
description: Birds are so intelligent.  They can solve puzzles, remember faces, and are some of the only critters who can reproduce human speech.  These are 3 deep cut skills though that really blew my mind.

title: Learn a Language Before You're Born?
description:
It's interesting that babies don't wait to start learning - they learn before they are born.  Also they don't learn vocabulary or grammar in the womb, they do pick up on cadence and rhythmic patterns of their parent's native language, and then demonstrate a preference for those linguistic qualities on the very first day they are born.

For more details and methodology, check out the August 2025 paper from Andr√©anne Ren√© et al: "Prenatal linguistic exposure shapes language brain responses at birth"

title: Canned pumpkin is a lie.
description:
The cans at the grocery store may say "100% Pure Pumpkin"... but that may not mean what you think it does.

Pumpkin Cinnamon Roll: @inbloombakery
Pumpkin Dog: @danastargazertruitt
Cucumber Pie: @adina.inspires

title: This Tree Has Been To The Moon
description: Around the world, 500 moon trees from the Apollo 14 mission have been planted! These trees came from seeds that orbited around the moon in a canister brought along by Command Module Captain Stuart Roosa.  You should search to see if there is one near you that is still alive!

title: Which State Eats the Most Ice Cream?
Women Beat Men In This Sport
description: In most traditional sports, men tend to have a physical advantage. Part of that might come from the fact that men have historically decided which activities even count as sports.   But there is one sport where women consistently outpace men. Can you guess which one?

title: We Will Miss This American Icon
description: America Online was my introduction to the internet! I haven't used it in 25 years, but apparently it has been in operation this entire time. Until last week, when it was finally phased out!

title: Will Flossing Replace The Flu Shot?
description: For years, scientists have been searching for alternatives to the dreaded flu shot.  They've had some success with the nasal spray, but it has its shortcomings. This year, researchers tested a vaccine delivered through dental floss, and it looks promising!

title: You Can Learn To See With Your Tongue
description:
The Brainport is one of the wildest inventions.  It turns images/video into a grid of gentle electrical patterns on the tongue.

 Essentially, a camera captures the scene ahead, and a small grid that rests on the tongue sends corresponding pulses that represent light and shape. With a few weeks of training, the brain learns to interpret these tongue sensations as visual input.   

This is possible  because of neuroplasticity. Your brain has the ability to rewire itself and assign new meaning to sensory data, allowing the tongue‚Äôs signals to activate areas of the brain normally used for vision.

title: Guess how much this safety net cost?
description:
Construction costs make no sense. 

When the Golden Gate Bridge was built in the 1930s, the total cost (adjusted for today) was about $600 million. That covered everything: massive pylons sunk into the bay, tons of steel, and a roadway suspended across the water.  But recently, just adding a single safety net. Guess how much it cost?  

The U.S. consistently spends way more on public works than other countries.

title: Who's Your Favorite Video Creator?
description:
I really like that learning a language is a way to invest your curiosity in a way that connects you to other people. Other hobbies can end up being kind of lonely, lol. 

Like, the more you learn about some topics like Ancient History or Obscure Films, it just shrinks the circle of people that you can talk to about it.  But when you learn a language, the circle only grows. 

So, there are a lot of creators that I admire, but @yuji_beleza  might  be my favorite. I'll watch each and every video to completion haha

title: Which State Eats The Most Pizza?
description: The famous pizza slices in the USA come from New York City, Chicago, Detroit, and California... but what state actually eats the most pizza? There are a few ways to approach that question. One would be to look at the total volume of pizza slices sold, but in this video we look at a metric from a nationwide survey done in 2025: the average days per month that the average resident of a state eats pizza.  Which state would you guess wins that contest?

title: You NEED a Code Word
description: With scammers getting faster and more sophisticated, it is really important to establish a codeword with your close friends and family!  Ideally, send them this video and then have a face to face conversation to settle on a word you can remember. The idea is that if someone is ever claiming to be you over a phone or video call, you could rely on the secret password to verify everyone is who they say they are.

title: What Video Will People Still Be Watching in 100 Years?
description: It's great that the National Film Registry was established in the 1980s, to preserve culturally important movies. This really helps because movie-watching technology will change, and the current streaming services will likely go out of business.   So the NFR will have to transfer the films onto whatever the medium of the future is.   However, it is interesting that the NFR has not accepted an online video yet, even though many online videos have just as much of a cultural footprint (and often a larger reach) than many feature films.   What internet video do you think should be preserved for the future?

title: The Trick Behind This Famous FX Shot
description:
The opening of Forrest Gump follows a feather drifting for over two minutes. It looks simple, but in 1993- when CGI was still in its infancy- this shot was insanely difficult. Using old-school tricks, Zemeckis & team stitched together a 2:30 stunner that remains one of the most ambitious VFX shots of its era.

It's playing for one day in theaters on September 14 as part of the Month of Masterpieces at @RegalMovies!  This isn't an ad, but you should check out the full schedule on their website, because a lot of these movies are very rarely on the big screen!

title: This Game Can Help After Trauma
description: Researchers have studied people immediately after traumatic car accidents, and they found that if you play Tetris for about half an hour within 6 hours of the event, you‚Äôre much less likely to develop intrusive memories and flashbacks later on.  That‚Äôs super helpful to know, because when you‚Äôre in shock the instinct can sometimes be to doomscroll, ruminate, or pray compulsively about what just happened- but those things can actually entrench traumatic memories and make long-term PTSD worse.

title: This Video Is Playing Upside Down?
description: It is wild to me that if you wear inversion goggles that flip your vision upside down, your brain will learn to ignore the effect after a few days, and your vision will return to normal.  Which must be a trip when you take the goggles off and are seeing the world upside down, even though you are viewing in through your natural eyes... (it takes a few days for the brain to switch back again) üò≥

title: Should This Movie Be Ranked #1?
How Movie Theaters Change Your Brain
description:
Home TV‚Äôs have gotten pretty good (and big, but there are some key differences in the spychological effects of watching a 4 foot all home TV and a 20 foot tall cinema screen. For more details, check out the paper ‚ÄúThe Effects of Screen Size and Message Content on Attention and Arousal‚Äù by Byron Reeves.

Interstellar is playing September 5 in @RegalMovies nationwide!

title: Did Cracker Barrel Fake Their Rebrand?
description: The Cracker Barrel redesign has been the TALK OF THE TOWN this week, but it feels pretty suspicious to me. The restaurant has a long history of clever marketing.  The whole whole chain actually got started by a Shell Oil exec who came up with the idea to stick Cracker Barrels next to gas stations to boost sales.  This logo rollout (and rapid reversal) seems like a smart way to remind customers of the brand‚Äôs old-timey roots.

title: The 2nd Oldest City in America
description:
St Augustine gets a lot of attention for being the oldest continuously populated European city in America... but the #2 City may surprised you. 

Of course, there were large indigenous metropolises on the continent throughout history, like Cahokia, which had more people than London and Paris at the time.

title: Where Do Movie Babies Come From?
description: Casting babies is a really unique challenge in filmmaking!  Unlike adult actors, babies can only pass for a very narrow age window.   That means productions are racing against the clock to find the right baby at the right moment.  Which is hard when film schedules can be notoriously unpredictable.   But there are professional baby wranglers out there who have got it down to a science and an art, lol.

title: The Most Expensive Phone Case in the World
description: I usually just buy my phone case the same day I buy my phone. But I‚Äôve been thinking maybe I should treat my phone case more like shoes, and have different ones for different occasions. Usually I am filming with my phone out and about, so I need something discreet and with a good grip on it. But for days when I am not filming, it probably would be good to have something that says something more.  As I was looking into the options out there, I was surprised by the range of stuff‚Ä¶ and the prices.

title: This City's Name Was Decided By Cointoss
description: One of the biggest cities on the West Coast was almost named "Boston."  I also was surprised to think about how after the American Revolution, England still held a claim in Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. I think I had generally assumed that after the war, the land disputes must've ended, but there was a whole other chapter in the PNW.

title: The Fish Jurassic Park Made Famous
description: The top 3 fish you'll find in restaurants today are salmon, tilapia, and Chilean sea bass. Interestingly, none of those were standards until roughly the 1970s. But I think the story behind Chilean Sea Bass is the most interesting, because it wasn't an issue of farming or supply. Just an instance of marketing.

title: How Movies Did Crowds Before CGI
description: Movies like Forrest Gump are interesting to me, because they were made right on the cusp of CGI. Although they did have some rudimentary computer tools, the filmmakers mostly had to rely on creativity to engineer shots that folks today can just crank out with CGI.  Part of what made movies like Jaws or Jurassic Park so compelling was that the director was working under limitations of what they could show the audience.

title: Only Americans Do This
description: The "American lean" is a cultural quirk where people from the U.S. instinctively lean on walls, railings, doorframes, or furniture when standing in public. It‚Äôs casual, relaxed, and often signals comfort in occupying space... but where did it come from?

title: The U.S. Capitol Almost Looked Like This
description: It‚Äôs striking that the statue atop our nation‚Äôs most important building was chosen by the President of the Confederacy- specifically to replace a design that included imagery of emancipation. But maybe,  there‚Äôs a chance to change that.

title: I just won an Olympic medal!
Does Every Movie Use A.I.?
description: AI is becoming more prevalent in filmmaking, not just for visual effects, but also for enhancing performances and streamlining production processes. While I understand the skepticism surrounding it, many moviegoers may not realize just how deeply AI is embedded in nearly every aspect of cinema‚Äîfrom lighting to sound to makeup. For example, when a movie recorded in stereo (2 channels) needs to be mixed for surround sound (5+ channels), the process isn't typically done entirely by hand. Instead, AI, trained on countless films mixed in surround sound, often takes on the bulk of the work.

title: How Your Printer Spies On You
description: A lot of color laser printers secretly print codes on every page that help the printer be recognized. The tech was originally supposed to help law enforcement track down criminals forensically- klike ransom notes, counterfeit money, that sort of thing. These tracking dots are usually only visible under LED or UV light, or if you scan in the document and crank up the contrast and saturation to an extreme. When I tested it out myself, I found a pattern of tiny red squares embedded in the text. I‚Äôm not sure if that was just an artifact from my scanner or an evolution of the code!

title: Your Brain Can't Do This (Until It's Taught)
description:
This video is based on a real study from Project Prakash, a program in India that helps children born blind gain sight through surgery. Scientists used this opportunity to test a 300-year-old thought experiment known as Molyneux‚Äôs Problem: if someone who was born blind learns to recognize objects like a ball or cube by touch, would they recognize them by sight once they could see? The answer? Not at first.

Right after surgery, the kids could still feel the difference between objects but couldn‚Äôt visually match what they saw to what they had once touched. Their brains didn‚Äôt yet connect sight with touch. But within a week, they learned the visual cues!

title: The World's Largest Gathering of Micronations
The Movie That Invented Movie Marketing
description:
Before Jaws, movies didn‚Äôt open everywhere at once. Studios treated them more like Broadway shows: a big film would premiere in a major city and then slowly expand to other theaters over months or even years. As you‚Äôll notice in the Sound of Music clip in this video, a major release might get its own permanent theater with elaborate signage and higher ticket prices. As a film built hype in one place, it would gradually ‚Äúgo on tour‚Äù to other cities.

But Jaws changed all that.

title: The Civilization That Actually Shaped Europe
description: The Roman Empire gets all the credit for shaping Europe... but the Vikings had just as big of an impact, and maybe a more surprising one. They didn‚Äôt just raid, they founded cities, ruled kingdoms, and left their mark all over the continent, from Ireland to Italy.   The countries that weren‚Äôt taken over by Vikings had to level up just to survive. A lot of the beautiful architecture that people admire in Europe was actually developed to keep Vikings out.

title: We Almost Built This National Monument
description:
The design of the Gateway Arch in St. Louis came from a public competition in the 1940s. Eero Saarinen‚Äôs sleek arch won- and became an American icon. But some of the rejected ideas were pretty great too.   If we had gone with the Old Man River statue instead, I can imagine people would still be traveling to see it thousands of years from now.

@explorestlouis

title: The Earth Is A Cube
description: An interesting thing about science: if you decide you want to believe something, like that the Earth is a cube, you can twist any piece of evidence to support it. That‚Äôs called ad hoc reasoning- making up explanations after the fact to protect a belief.  But just because a theory COULD BE POSSIBLE doesn‚Äôt mean there‚Äôs any evidence for it.

title: Only 6 of these exist? (Part 1)
description:
Here are a few things you may be surprised to learn there are only six of!
@Apple  @oscarmayer

title: The Craziest Thing About Holograms
description:
Holograms seem almost unbelievable - the idea that you can capture full 3D information about an object on a flat piece of glass, and view it from a smooth range of angles.  

If you want to understand how it actually works, check out Grant‚Äôs video (@3blue1brown ) that breaks down the procedure and math behind it: how splitting a laser creates an interference pattern that gets recorded on the glass, giving the hologram its 3D effect.  It's one of the best ways you can spend 45 minutes.

title: Can Anyone Beat This Movie Record?
description: Sometimes a movie is so good you have to see it twice. Maybe even three times. But one guy took it to a whole new level. To officially count each viewing, he had to watch the entire movie - no phone, no bathroom breaks, start to finish.

title: Our Micronation Is Turning 10,000!
description:
Where did Ironland actually come from? I dug into the Asheville archives and found some incredible photos and early sketches- all pointing back to one artist. The origin story might surprise you.

@exploreasheville

title: 3 Micronations Ironland Will Meet At Microcon
description: MicroCon is the biggest gathering of micronations in the world! This year, it‚Äôs hosted by three wildly different countries that perfectly showcase the diversity of nations who will be in attendance.

title: The Real Reason The Cannes Film Festival Exists
description: Cannes is happening this week‚Ä¶ but its origin story may surprise you!

title: Two World Records You Could Beat
description: Some world records seem like they would take decades of training. Other seems... a bit more within reach.

title: Movies shouldn't cost more than $25M
description: I was shocked to learn how small the budgets are for Wes Anderson movies. Even though The Grand Budapest Hotel is extremely lush and visually exciting, they were able to shoot it for only $25M. Same with Asteroid City. That's like the same cost of shooting a run-of-the-mill Netflix flick with a couple of stars an no real production design. When I see how other filmmakers like Yorgos Lanthimos can shoot Poor Things on $35M, it is hard to see a reason why any movie (other than super special epics) would ever need to cost more than that.

title: Every movie has this, prove me wrong.
description: I've spent the last week trying to think of an example of a movie that doesn't show someone eating or drinking, but I am convinced it doesn't exist.

title: What's A Movie Will People Still Watch in 100 Years?
description: There were over 800 movies made in 1925, but only 2-3 of them are regularly watched by people today.  So what movies from today do you think people will still be watching 100 years in the future?

title: The First Movie to Ever Use a Green Screen
description: Today‚Äôs movies rely on green screens for everything from superhero battles to fake windows‚Äîbut did you know filmmakers were using this trick long before computers even existed?

title: The Loudest Camera In The World
description: Not a lot of movies are shot on true IMAX film ‚Äî mostly because it‚Äôs a pain. The cameras are huge, expensive... and super loud. Directors like Christopher Nolan (Oppenheimer, Dunkirk), Jordan Peele (Nope), and  the most recent James Bond team used IMAX for some scenes, but it comes with a weird challenge: the camera is so loud it makes shooting dialogue really hard.

title: This President Just Visited Ironland
This TV Setting Ruins Movies
description: For some reason, most new TVs come with this setting turned on. It's great for sports and nature documentaries, but will make any show or movie look so bad.

title: The Best Movie Soundtrack of 2025?
description: I was on the fence about seeing this until I saw that Ludwig Goransson was doing the score. (He was worked with Ryan Coogler on all his projects since Fruitvale Station back in 2013).   I listen to Goransson's score for Oppenheimer once every couple days, but he has really done something special here with Sinners.  This video isn't sponsored by anyone, I was just really delighted by the score in this movie.

title: The Most Expensive Movie Poster In The World
description:
The first movie poster ever was made in 1895 for a short film about a gardener watering his lawn. The idea was to convince people on the street to pay the fee to go inside the theater and watch it.

Today, vintage movie posters are highly sought after by collectors not just for their connection to classic films but also for their artistic value.

But which film poster has sold for the most money?

title: The Movie Snack Before Popcorn
description: Interestingly, oysters were once a popular snack at the theater, especially in the 1600s. In fact, archaeologists discovered layers of discarded oyster shells at Shakespeare's Globe Theater.  This trend continued all the way through vaudeville theater in the 1910s until they were replaced by popcorn during the Great Depression.

title: The Most Watched Actor In The World
description:
@LetterboxdHQ  is a social network where movie lovers track their films and write reviews. Every time a movie is logged as watched, each actor in the film gets a point, and at the end of the year, Letterboxd compiles a list of the most-watched actors based on user activity.

While you might assume big pop culture stars like Timoth√©e Chalamet or Brad Pitt would take the top spots, the data tells a different story.

title: Can You Think Of A Hand Gesture That Doesn't Mean Anything?
description: Most hand gesture variations have already been claimed. So, what happens when you try to create a new gesture? Is it possible to make one that doesn‚Äôt mean anything at all?

title: How Star Wars Did Lightsabers Before CGI
description:
Star Wars didn't just showcase impressive special effects‚Äîit invented many of the foundational concepts behind modern filmmaking. Industrial Light & Magic (ILM) pioneered groundbreaking techniques, like John Dykstra‚Äôs motion-control camera system, which allowed spaceships and the Death Star to be filmed in separate shots yet perfectly synchronized through precisely repeatable camera movements. ILM also advanced rotoscoping techniques, stop-motion animation, and early forms of motion capture. Beyond visuals, Star Wars revolutionized audio, becoming the first film to credit a "Sound Designer," a role invented for Ben Burtt, who created iconic sounds like lightsabers and blasters.

@disneyplus

title: The Sun Has Voted in An Election
description: In 2003, something bizarre happened during a Belgian election: a politician received exactly 4,096 unexpected votes. It wasn‚Äôt fraud, and it wasn‚Äôt a software bug‚Äîit was space. A stray particle from the sun struck a voting computer's memory chip and caused what's known as a Single Event Upset (SEU). That‚Äôs when radiation flips a single bit in a computer‚Äôs memory, turning a 0 into a 1. In this case, that flipped bit was in the 13th position of a binary number‚Äîadding exactly 2¬π¬≤, or 4,096 votes, to the candidate‚Äôs total. The vote didn‚Äôt hold up, thanks to an audit trail, but the incident became a legendary example of how fragile electronic voting can be without backups. It's one of the only times you can say the sun literally interfered with democracy.

title: The World's Newest Country Is Almost Here
description: There are currently 195 official countries in the United Nations, with South Sudan holding the title of the world's newest recognized country since 2011. But this title could soon pass to Bougainville‚Äîa pair of islands in the Pacific, currently part of Papua New Guinea. In a recent referendum, an overwhelming 98% of Bougainville‚Äôs 300,000 citizens voted in favor of independence.

title: The President Who Invented A Hand Gesture
description: Bill Clinton is the only U.S. president with a hand gesture named after him: the ‚ÄúClinton thumb.‚Äù This subtle gesture involves pressing the thumb against the index finger while making a fist, often with the hand slightly bouncing for emphasis. It became a signature part of his public speaking style‚Äîauthoritative without being aggressive, confident without pointing. The Clinton thumb was praised by communication coaches and political strategists for softening strong rhetoric and conveying sincerity. Unlike the more jabbing gestures of past politicians, Clinton‚Äôs thumb allowed him to make forceful points without appearing confrontational.

title: Ironland‚Äôs First Diplomatic Mission
description:
MicroCon is the biggest event in the micronation world. This year, it‚Äôs happening in Montreal, Canada‚Äîand Ironland should be there.

That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre assembling the Diplomacy Team‚Äîa group of citizens who will help decide which micronations we should ally with, how we can secure a spot at the exclusive gala, and more. If you want to be part of Ironland‚Äôs international strategy, follow the link on my linktree to get sworn into the Diplomacy Team.

title: The Strangest Ritual in Tennis
description:
Most sports have a strict divide between opponents‚Äîteams warm up separately, fighters prepare in isolation, and even friendly pregame interactions are limited. But tennis has a fascinating quirk: before every match, rivals help each other warm up. This tradition isn‚Äôt just for show; it allows both players to adjust to the court, get a feel for conditions, and fine-tune their timing.

This practice dates back to tennis‚Äôs aristocratic origins, where sportsmanship and etiquette were as important as competition.

title: This Bible Character Has The Wrong Name
description:
One of the most infamous names in history might not be what you think. The disciple who betrays Jesus for 30 pieces of silver is popularly known as "Judas"‚Äîbut his name is actually Judah. That might not seem like a big deal, but it connects him directly to an earlier biblical figure: Judah, who also sold his brother for silver.

In his blog, ‚Äã ‚Å®@bartdehrman explores the idea that this name was an intentional choice to emphasize the fact that Jesus was being betrayed by his own people. (Judah is where we get the word "Jew" from.). However, he doesn't think the case is ultimately persuasive enough.

title: Why The Severance Carpet Is Neon Green
description:
Filmmaking often requires adjusting colors on set to achieve the right look in the final product. The carpet in Severance is a great example‚Äîit appears as a muted teal in the show, but on set, it was actually an intense green.  This was a deliberate choice to compensate for the planned color grade, which reduced green tones in skin. Since that process also affects other greens in the environment, the production team exaggerated the carpet color to ensure it looked right in the final image.

This technique has been used throughout film history. In The Wizard of Oz, Dorothy‚Äôs ruby slippers were actually dark burgundy because Technicolor processing would have made true red look overly bright. Similarly, filmmakers adjust speeds, lighting, and even material textures to ensure they look correct on screen.

title: Should Trees Have Legal Rights?
The Most Inconvenient Name In the World
The Only Movie Made By the CIA
description:
Although the CIA is usually associated with intelligence gathering, it occasionally interacts with Hollywood. The Agency often provides advice to film projects dealing with national security, like Argo, The Hurt Locker, and Mission Impossible. Even though they consult on numerous films, they seldom take a hands-on approach.

One surprising exception is the 1950s cartoon adaptation of Orwell‚Äôs Animal Farm. Here, the CIA not only encouraged the project but actually financed and produced the film. Orwell‚Äôs story‚Äîabout farm animals overthrowing humans, only for the pigs to become oppressors‚Äîwas a critique of totalitarianism in all forms. Yet the CIA saw it as a potent vehicle for anti-Communist ideas during the Cold War. They viewed it as a propaganda piece to shift public opinion. The Agency believed film was a medium to sway sentiment.

Notably, the Agency altered the original ending to show a successful uprising against new oppressors, transforming Orwell‚Äôs cyclical warning about tyranny into a direct triumph of freedom over communism. This rare example underscores the CIA‚Äôs willingness to shape narratives for strategic goals, making Animal Farm the only known movie the Agency produced

title: The Restaurant That Invented a Language
description:
Waffle House has a secret language‚Äîbut instead of words or pictures, it‚Äôs written in condiments. Their cooks don‚Äôt rely on traditional order slips. Instead, they arrange packets of jelly, butter, mayonnaise, and other small items in specific positions on a plate or tray to indicate egg styles, meat choices, and side dishes.  This seemingly simple system is actually an efficient form of proto-writing, similar to the ways ancient cultures communicated before alphabets or pictographs existed.

One striking historical parallel is the Scythians‚Äô response to Darius the Great in the 6th century BCE. Instead of sending a letter, they sent a box filled with arrows, a bird, a mouse, and a frog. Each object symbolized a warning: retreat, or we will attack from land, sky, and water. This method of conveying messages through the strategic arrangement of physical objects resembles Waffle House‚Äôs marking system. Both use tangible items in a structured, coded way to communicate essential information instantly.

title: The First Crossword Puzzle Ever
description:
The first-ever crossword puzzle was published on December 21, 1913, in the New York World newspaper. Created by journalist Arthur Wynne, it was called a "Word-Cross" and had a diamond-shaped grid with simple clues. It quickly gained popularity, and after a typesetting error flipped the title to "Cross-Word," the name stuck.

Initially dismissed as a fleeting craze, crossword puzzles exploded in popularity during the 1920s, especially after The New York Times introduced its own puzzle in 1942, elevating it to an intellectual pastime. Over the decades, crosswords have remained the world‚Äôs most popular word game, evolving into digital formats, cryptic variations, and themed challenges. They are now a daily ritual for millions, appearing in newspapers, books, and mobile apps.

Can you solve it?

title: The Country That Leaves Its Babies On The Street
description:
When measuring a nation's success, Gross Domestic Product (GDP) has long been the standard metric. However, GDP only captures economic output‚Äîit doesn‚Äôt reflect quality of life, happiness, or societal well-being. Alternative rankings, like the Better Life Index (BLI), consider factors like healthcare, education, income equality, social trust, and work-life balance.

Denmark consistently ranks among the world‚Äôs happiest countries. While its GDP is high, its well-being scores are even higher due to  free healthcare and education, a robust work-life balance, and strong social trust as evidenced by the practice of leaving babies out to nap outside of shops.

title: Welcome Back To Ironland
description:
We are the world‚Äôs fastest-growing micronation! If you‚Äôre new here, let‚Äôs catch you up.

Ironland is a sovereign nation founded on a 12-foot circle of land in North Carolina. (@exploreasheville ) What started as a small experiment quickly became a worldwide movement. In just one year, Ironland grew to over 200,000 citizens, established embassies in 50 countries, and even had its flag appear on the field of a professional football team in Ireland.  Oh and we made friends with Romania. 

But every great nation faces challenges‚Ä¶

Last year, a flood hit the surrounding city, and then a rogue knitting gang invaded, covering our entire territory in a giant crochet glove. Yes, really.

After months of effort, Ironland has been liberated from yarn, and we‚Äôre officially back. And this time, we‚Äôre leveling up.

To shape Ironland‚Äôs future, we‚Äôre assembling three special teams, and we need your help:

üîπ Diplomacy Team ‚Äì This summer, the world‚Äôs biggest micronation summit, MicroCon, is happening in Montreal. Leaders from real-life micronations around the world will be there, and Ironland should be too. The Diplomacy Team‚Äôs mission? Help Ironland secure a seat at MicroCon and decide which micronations we should form alliances with.

üéµ Anthem Team ‚Äì Every great nation needs a great anthem. Ironland is finally getting its own national anthem, and this team will help create and record it. Whether you‚Äôre musically gifted or just have strong opinions on what makes an anthem iconic, this is your chance to make history.

üìç Land Team ‚Äì For the first time ever, Ironland is being mapped into individual plots, and every citizen will be assigned their own piece of land‚Äîfor free. The Land Team will help design and organize this historic moment, giving every citizen an official place in Ironland.

title: The Movie That Invented The Blue Dress Shirt
description:
Have you ever wondered why so many men today choose blue dress shirts, especially in professional settings? Not too long ago, white was the only acceptable option for business attire. 

The white dress shirt has long been synonymous with formality, respectability, and social status. Its origins trace back to the 19th century, when laundering was labor-intensive and only the wealthy could afford the time and expense to keep a garment perfectly white. Because any dirt or stain was immediately visible, wearing a spotless white shirt broadcast one‚Äôs ability to remain clean (and thus employed) without performing manual labor. This distinction gave rise to the term ‚Äúwhite-collar,‚Äù as opposed to ‚Äúblue-collar‚Äù workers who often wore durable, darker fabrics that could mask stains.

Even U.S. Presidents stuck to white, with Harry Truman‚Äôs Hawaiian shirt being an outlier‚Äîand that was on vacation. But John F. Kennedy famously embraced a blue shirt, and the shift was on. 

According to color theorist Faber Birren, James Bond played a pivotal role. JFK‚Äôs favorite movie, ‚ÄúDr. No,‚Äù showcased the suave spy sporting blue shirts, giving men an exciting new style to emulate. Suddenly, sporting color to the office seemed both fashionable and sophisticated.

title: A Baby Will Beat You at This Test
description:
Babies are born with an incredible range of abilities, both auditory and visual, that allow them to perceive the world in ways adults cannot. They can distinguish between sounds from every language, recognize subtle differences in faces across species, and process details that seem insignificant to older brains. However, many of these abilities fade over time due to a process called perceptual narrowing.

Perceptual narrowing is the brain‚Äôs way of streamlining its skills based on experience. As babies grow, their brains prioritize what‚Äôs useful in their environment and gradually discard abilities that aren‚Äôt needed. For example, while a six-month-old can easily tell apart different monkey faces, most adults struggle to do the same. Similarly, babies can initially hear sound distinctions from all languages, but by their first birthday, they become attuned only to the languages they hear regularly. This process shapes how we interact with the world and defines what we perceive.

For more info, check out the paper:
"Plasticity of face processing in infancy" by O. Pascalis (2005)

title: They Named This Body Part Wrong
description:
The quadriceps, or "quads," got their name centuries ago, derived from the Latin quadriceps femoris, meaning "four-headed muscle of the thigh." This muscle group includes four parts: the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius. These muscles work together to extend the knee and stabilize the leg, making them essential for walking, running, and jumping. For centuries, anatomists believed they had fully mapped this crucial group.

However, modern anatomical studies have revealed a surprising twist: there‚Äôs a fifth part of the quadriceps, called the tensor of the vastus intermedius. Discovered through advanced imaging and cadaver studies, this small but distinct muscle lies between the vastus intermedius and vastus lateralis. Though not as prominent as its four "siblings," it contributes to the overall function of the quadriceps and challenges the historical naming of the muscle group.

The paper first describing the new muscle:
"A newly discovered muscle: The tensor of the vastus intermedius"  K Grob et al (2016)

For an overview of all the studies regarding the new muscle, search for: "Tensor vastus intermedius: a review of its discovery, morphology and clinical importance" by T. Franchi.

Preacher Curl clip from: @KZFITNESS . Check out their channel for a great library of gym movements.

title: 3 Words You Didn't Realize Are Hiding in Other Words
description:
Language is like a living museum, where words carry fragments of the past, often hidden in plain sight. Over centuries, as languages evolve and meanings shift, ancient roots can become embedded in modern words, quietly carrying their original significance into contexts far removed from their origins. These fragments often go unnoticed, leaving us unaware of the vivid history tucked into our everyday speech.

Take muscle, for example, derived from the Latin musculus, meaning "little mouse." The Romans thought flexing muscles resembled mice scurrying under the skin‚Äîa delightful image now forgotten by most. Similarly, salary hides its root in salarium, a reference to salt, once a form of Roman payment. Words like window (vindauga, "wind-eye" in Old Norse) and umbrella (from umbra, Latin for "shade") also preserve ancient nouns, their original meanings obscured by time and usage.

title: Why Are British Dogs So Well Behaved?
description:
I just got back from a trip to London, and it surpassed all my expectations. The city is steeped in centuries of history, from regal palaces to lively pubs, but what really caught my attention was the dogs! Everywhere I went‚ÄîHyde Park, bustling markets, quaint cobblestone streets‚ÄîI saw dogs walking calmly off-leash, navigating crowds with impressive ease. It was fascinating to see these pups behave so well in a busy urban environment, often exploring freely while still responding obediently to their owners. Unlike in many other places I‚Äôve visited, there seemed to be a strong emphasis on early training and socialization, ensuring the dogs fit seamlessly into city life. Hardly any barking, lunging, or chaos‚Äîjust wagging tails and friendly interactions. 

Chow Chow clip from: @carlcunard1

title: The Country That Likes China The Least
description:
Individuals in different countries hold varying views on the United States and China, shaped by historical relationships, cultural exchanges, and geopolitical dynamics. A 2024 Pew Research survey revealed striking differences in favorability toward these two global powers, ranking countries based on the degree of public support for either nation.

Historical context often plays a significant role in shaping perceptions. For example, countries with longstanding alliances with the U.S., such as Japan, South Korea, and several Western European nations, tend to hold positive views of the U.S. due to shared security agreements and economic ties. Conversely, nations with histories of tension or intervention, like Russia and parts of the Middle East, often express lower favorability toward the U.S.

China‚Äôs favorability is similarly nuanced. Many African nations view China positively due to its significant investment in infrastructure and trade relations under the Belt and Road Initiative.

To read the study and see how these countries rated the U.S. on several other dimension search for the July 2024  paper from Pew Research Titled "Comparing Views of the U.S. and China in 24 Countries.‚Äù

title: The Beverage That Gave Us Color Printing
description:
The reason we can print in color today traces back to an unexpected source: beer, and a man named Joseph Lovibond. Lovibond, a 19th-century London brewmaster, was obsessed with quality and consistency. For him, a perfect pint of beer wasn‚Äôt just about taste‚Äîit had to look right too. But judging beer color by eye proved unreliable; human perception was subjective, and lighting conditions varied.

One day, while admiring the stained glass windows of a cathedral, Lovibond had a flash of inspiration. He realized that by layering thin sheets of colored glass, he could precisely match the color of his beer. Building on this idea, he invented the tintometer, a device that used glass slides in standardized shades of cyan, yellow, and magenta to measure color with remarkable accuracy.

Lovibond‚Äôs tintometer revolutionized the brewing industry, setting a new standard for color consistency. But his innovation didn‚Äôt stop there. The principles behind his device were eventually adopted in color printing, where layering cyan, magenta, and yellow inks became the foundation for reproducing vibrant images.

Please look up the full beautiful stained glass timelapse from @nicholasberardo4699

title: The Worst Portraits on Wikipedia
description:
Wikipedia is a goldmine of information, but its photos of public figures often leave something to be desired. Unlike glossy magazine covers or professionally curated Instagram profiles, the images on Wikipedia must adhere to strict copyright rules. They often rely on Creative Commons licenses or public domain images, which can severely limit the pool of available photos. As a result, Wikipedia articles frequently feature candid snapshots from press events, grainy photos taken by amateurs, or awkward moments immortalized at just the wrong time.

Professional headshots and polished publicity stills are usually off-limits unless explicitly released under an appropriate license, which most celebrities and their teams rarely do. This leads to a peculiar phenomenon where some of the most iconic faces in the world are represented online by some of their least flattering images. While these photos may not always capture individuals in their best light, they highlight Wikipedia‚Äôs commitment to open access and free use, even if that occasionally means sacrificing a bit of aesthetic quality for the greater good of information sharing.

title: A Better Way To Do New Year's Resolutions
description:
New Year‚Äôs resolutions can be exciting in January, but let‚Äôs be honest‚Äîthey often lose steam by February. Many of us set big goals only to feel guilty or defeated when we fall short. But what if there was a more fun and flexible way to approach your aspirations for the year? Enter the New Year‚Äôs Bingo card.

Instead of committing to a single resolution, start with an empty 5x5 Bingo grid. In each square, write something you‚Äôd like to experience, achieve, or try in the coming year. These can range from small, joyful moments‚Äîlike eating a freshly dipped corndog‚Äîto ambitious goals, like attending a conference or learning a new skill. The beauty of this approach is its flexibility. You‚Äôre not stuck chasing one big goal; you have 25 opportunities (well, 24 plus the free space) to make your year interesting and fulfilling.

Throughout the year, crossing off squares becomes a rewarding mini-celebration. And as December rolls around, the Bingo card encourages you to tackle those remaining squares to aim for a full ‚ÄúBINGO.‚Äù

title: The Real Meaning of Mistletoe
description:
Mistletoe, the festive plant we associate with kisses and holiday cheer, has an origin story that's far less romantic. Its name comes from Old English, where mistel means dung and tan or toe means twig. Together, they form "dung-on-a-twig"‚Äîa nod to how mistletoe grows.

This peculiar name arose because mistletoe seeds are spread through bird droppings. Birds eat the plant‚Äôs berries and excrete the seeds, which conveniently stick to tree branches, germinating into the parasitic plant we recognize. This unflattering start contrasts sharply with mistletoe's later reputation as a symbol of love and fertility.

In ancient cultures, mistletoe held mystical significance due to its ability to thrive in winter when other plants withered. It became a symbol of life and renewal, eventually morphing into a romantic tradition. So next time you share a kiss under mistletoe, remember‚Äîyou‚Äôre celebrating dung‚Äôs unlikely role in festive romance!

Gorgeous wreath stitched from: @JennysWreathBoutique

title: The Grammar Errors in The Book of Mormon
description:
The original 1830 edition of the Book of Mormon displayed numerous grammatical irregularities, awkward phrasings, and nonstandard constructions. Its syntax at times mirrored an archaic, biblically influenced style, yet also included forms and expressions uncommon in standard nineteenth-century English. Many of these peculiarities stood out to early readers, who found the text‚Äôs language unconventional and at odds with the polished prose they would expect from divine scripture. Critics argued that such awkwardness raised doubts about its purported ancient origins. They contended that a genuinely inspired translation of a centuries-old record should not produce grammatical anomalies seemingly rooted in Joseph Smith‚Äôs own language environment.

In recent decades, linguist and scholar Royal Skousen has attempted to address these issues through his extensive ‚ÄúAnalysis of Textual Variants of the Book of Mormon.‚Äù Skousen‚Äôs work delves into the earliest manuscripts and printed editions, examining every variant word and phrase. His goal is to understand the text‚Äôs linguistic origins, clarify the nature of its dictation, and determine how best to explain the non-standard grammar.

title: How to Find Your Location Without GPS
description:
For centuries, finding latitude and longitude was crucial for maritime navigation, allowing sailors to pinpoint their position on the vast and featureless seas. Latitude, the measure of distance north or south of the equator, was relatively easy to determine. Ancient mariners used instruments like the sextant to measure the angle of the sun at noon or the altitude of stars like Polaris above the horizon. This measurement, combined with charts and tables, revealed their latitude.

Longitude, the measure of distance east or west of a prime meridian, was a far more complex challenge. Sailors needed to know the precise time at a fixed location (such as Greenwich) and compare it to the local time determined by the sun's position. The difference allowed them to calculate their longitude, as Earth rotates 15 degrees per hour. This required a reliable timepiece, which wasn‚Äôt achieved until the 18th century with the invention of the marine chronometer by John Harrison. Before this, inaccurate methods often led to disastrous navigation errors.

Today, latitude and longitude can be found using modern GPS, but understanding the historical methods underscores the ingenuity of early navigators, who relied on precise instruments, celestial observations, and a deep knowledge of mathematics to cross the world's oceans.

title: The Only Color With No Dark Side
description:
Colors carry meaning‚Äîsometimes uplifting, sometimes negative. Blue is beloved for its association with calm skies and serene waters, but it‚Äôs also tied to melancholy (‚Äúfeeling blue‚Äù) and risqu√© humor (‚Äúblue jokes‚Äù). Green, the color of life and renewal, carries shadows of envy (‚Äúgreen with envy‚Äù), inexperience (‚Äúgreenhorn‚Äù), and even a sickly pallor. Yellow radiates warmth and happiness but turns jaundiced‚Äîa name for a yellowing sickness. Even regal purple has its downsides, becoming ‚Äúbruised‚Äù or heavy-handed in certain contexts.

Red, vibrant and passionate, often signals danger, anger, or vulgarity when it becomes garish. From ashy browns to pale grays, virtually every color has a skeleton in its closet.

But not orange. According to Faber Birren, a renowned color theorist, orange is unique in its immunity to negativity. Birren pointed out that orange was named relatively late‚Äîcenturies after green and purple‚Äîand it has ‚Äúvirtually no negative associations.‚Äù Despite its links to traffic cones, safety vests, and even prison jumpsuits, orange has no universal word to describe a ‚Äúbad‚Äù shade.

title: This Illusion Proves You're In The Matrix
description:
Akiyoshi Kitaoka‚Äôs latest optical illusion, featuring two faces that appear to differ in luminance‚Äîone seeming white, the other black‚Äîbeautifully illustrates Immanuel Kant‚Äôs distinction between noumena (things-in-themselves) and phenomena (things as they appear to us). Despite being physically identical in color (their noumenal reality), the faces are perceived as dramatically different due to contextual factors influencing our sensory and cognitive processes.

In Kant‚Äôs framework, noumena represent the objective reality that exists independently of human perception. Here, the color of the faces, objectively the same, belongs to the noumenal realm. However, phenomena are the reality we experience, shaped by the mind‚Äôs interpretative filters. In Kitaoka‚Äôs illusion, our perception of luminance is skewed by the surrounding elements‚Äîlighting cues, shadow gradients, and contextual contrasts. These environmental factors trick our visual system, making the faces appear as opposites in brightness.

This illusion demonstrates how the mind imposes its structures and biases on raw sensory input, constructing a phenomenal reality that often diverges from the underlying noumenal truth.

title: Is This Painting Worth $121M?
description:
Ren√© Magritte‚Äôs L‚Äôempire des lumi√®res recently sold for over $121 million at a Christie‚Äôs auction, shattering the record for the Surrealist artist‚Äôs work. While such astronomical prices often provoke skepticism‚Äîsome dismissing art as a playground for financial speculation or even money laundering‚ÄîMagritte‚Äôs creations deserve recognition for their profound ideas, which extend far beyond the market‚Äôs frenzy.

Magritte‚Äôs most famous works‚Äîlike the iconic Ceci n‚Äôest pas une pipe‚Äîquestion the assumptions we make about reality, language, and meaning. This intellectual playfulness is central to his art‚Äôs enduring significance. While the art market may inflate prices to dazzling heights, the true value of Magritte‚Äôs work lies in its ability to unsettle, inspire, and transform how we engage with the world.

title: The Real Reason PIN Numbers Exist
description:
PIN numbers are four-digit codes most of us use without much thought, but they reveal fascinating patterns in human behavior. With only 10,000 possible combinations, you'd think PINs would be equally distributed‚Äîbut they're not.

The most common PIN, by far, is 1234. In fact, it‚Äôs so popular that nearly 11% of people use it. Other frequent choices include simple patterns like 1111 or 0000, which are easy to remember but also easy for a thief to guess. Birthdays are another go-to option. Dates like 1984 or 0704 (July 4th) appear frequently because they‚Äôre meaningful to us.

What‚Äôs surprising is how even the keypad layout influences choices. For example, 2580, which runs straight down the middle of a phone keypad, is disproportionately common‚Äîpossibly because it feels intuitive or visually satisfying.

At the other end of the spectrum, the least popular PINs are random-looking combinations like 8068 or 8093. They‚Äôre rarely chosen because they lack memorable patterns or personal significance.

title: The Best Preserved Castle Isn't Where You Think
description:
The Isle of Man, nestled in the Irish Sea between England, Ireland, Scotland, and Wales, holds a unique vantage point that has shaped its historical narrative for over 2,000 years. Its strategic location made it a crossroads for ancient civilizations, a trade hub, and a sought-after stronghold for empires and kingdoms vying for control of the British Isles.

During the Viking era, it became a linchpin in maritime networks, serving as both a raiding base and a settlement. The Vikings established Tynwald, the island‚Äôs parliament, which still operates today and is one of the oldest continuous legislative bodies in the world.

Later, as empires expanded, the Isle of Man found itself under Scottish, English, and Norse rule, absorbing a blend of cultures while maintaining its unique identity. Its position allowed it to remain somewhat insulated from direct conflict, preserving artifacts, traditions, and structures like Castle Rushen.

Today, the Isle of Man offers an unparalleled time capsule of history‚Äîa small island with stories of Celts, Vikings, and Manx etched into its landscape, all enriched by its status as a geographic and cultural nexus.  (@VisitIsleofMan2021)

title: A.I. vs Human Art
description:
Frans Hals‚Äôs "Regentesses of the Old Men‚Äôs Almshouse" is a compelling example of his raw, expressive style, capturing the women who oversaw the almshouse that supported him in his final years in poverty. Painted in 1664, it reveals the unvarnished character of these elderly regentesses, their authority etched into austere expressions. Hals‚Äôs rough, visible brushstrokes and muted colors convey a tension that may reflect his own feelings‚Äîresentment, envy, or perhaps reluctant gratitude toward those in charge of his care.

This deeply personal layer is something that is difficult for A.I. art  to replicate. While A.I. can mimic brushstrokes and color schemes, it lacks the intimate, nuanced relationship between artist and subject. Hals‚Äôs painting holds a palpable connection to his life‚Äôs hardships, an authenticity grounded in human experience that A.I., without personal stakes or emotions, simply cannot capture.

Adapted from on essay by John Berger in "Ways of Seeing".

title: Should Voting Be Mandatory?
description:
Compulsory voting is the idea that everyone eligible should be required by law to vote in elections. Twenty-one countries, including Australia, enforce this with penalties like fines or restrictions on accessing services. The goal is to ensure high voter turnout and make election results more representative of the entire population. Supporters argue that mandatory voting strengthens democracy by giving a voice to all groups, not just those who are highly motivated. It could also encourage governments to consider broader interests, knowing that more diverse voters will weigh in.

However, there are drawbacks. Critics claim it infringes on personal freedom, forcing people to vote even if they are uninformed or disinterested. They also argue that it might lead to a high number of random or protest votes, reducing the overall quality of electoral outcomes.

title: The Original Halloween Vegetable
description: Before pumpkins became the iconic vegetable of Halloween, the Celtic nations, like Ireland, Scotland, and the Isle of Man carved turnips for celebrations. Festivals like Samhain and Hop Tun Aa marked the end of the harvest and the beginning of the dark winter season, was deeply connected with the spirit world. It was believed that during this time, the veil between the living and the dead was thinnest, allowing spirits and fairies to cross into our realm. To ward off malevolent spirits, people would carve grotesque faces into hollowed-out turnips and place them near doors and windows. The scary faces were intended to frighten away wandering souls or mischievous fairies.

title: The Two Hidden Words in Genesis 1:1
description:
The first verse of the Bible, Genesis 1:1, is only seven words in the original Hebrew: ‚Äú◊ë÷∞÷º◊®÷µ◊ê◊©÷¥◊Å◊ô◊™ ◊ë÷∏÷º◊®÷∏◊ê ◊ê÷±◊ú÷π◊î÷¥◊ô◊ù ◊ê÷µ◊™ ◊î÷∑◊©÷∏÷º◊Å◊û÷∑◊ô÷¥◊ù ◊ï÷∞◊ê÷µ◊™ ◊î÷∏◊ê÷∏◊®÷∂◊•‚Äù ("In the beginning, God created the heavens and the earth"). Though brief, this verse poses several translation challenges in syntax, vocabulary, and grammar.

First, Hebrew syntax can be ambiguous. The phrase ‚Äúin the beginning‚Äù (◊ë÷∞÷º◊®÷µ◊ê◊©÷¥◊Å◊ô◊™) could imply an absolute beginning or simply a beginning of a particular event, leading to variations like ‚ÄúWhen God began to create‚Ä¶‚Äù vs. ‚ÄúIn the beginning, God created‚Ä¶.‚Äù The difference can influence theological interpretations.

There are even 2 words that aren't translated at all into English.

Recently I sat down with Alex O'Connor (@CosmicSkeptic ) for an episode for his podcast "Within Reason."  In our conversation, we did a deep dive on 7 intreresting problems with the popular English interpretation of Genesis 1:1.

title: Ireland Will Pay you $100K To Move Here
description:
Ireland‚Äôs ‚ÄúOur Living Islands‚Äù program offers a unique opportunity for those longing to escape the fast-paced city life and embrace a slower, more tranquil lifestyle. Launched by the Irish government, this initiative aims to rejuvenate 30 of Ireland‚Äôs most scenic, yet sparsely populated, offshore islands. The goal is simple: attract new residents to breathe life into these remote communities while preserving their charm and heritage.

Through this program, individuals who purchase and own a vacant property built before 1993, which has remained unoccupied for at least two years, can receive up to ‚Ç¨84,000 (around $92,000). This generous financial support is specifically allocated for refurbishing these homes, covering everything from essential structural repairs to aesthetic improvements. By doing so, Ireland hopes to turn these abandoned buildings into vibrant homes once again, revitalizing the islands‚Äô economies and maintaining their cultural landscapes.

While similar programs exist globally, Ireland‚Äôs stands out due to its generous financial backing and the chance to live amidst breathtaking coastal beauty. However, prospective participants must be aware that owning property in Ireland doesn‚Äôt automatically grant residency. Those interested will need to explore visa options or even dual citizenship if eligible. It‚Äôs an ideal path for those seeking adventure, a fresh start, and a community-centered lifestyle.

title: The First Micronation To Ever Have a Sports Team
description:
Ironland has made history by becoming the first micronation ever to secure an official sports team, partnering with Galway United, one of Ireland's beloved football clubs. With a growing population of over 200,000 citizens, Ironland has thrived as a unique and influential micronation despite recent challenges like Hurricane Helene. Its passionate community united, petitioning Galway United to represent Ironland as its national team. This unprecedented achievement highlights the power of community and collaboration, showing how a small, creative nation can make an impact on the global stage. Ironland citizens are now eagerly rallying behind Galway United, bringing their signature enthusiasm and dedication to every match.

Galway United, based in Galway City on the west coast of Ireland, is a club with deep roots and a dedicated fan base. Founded in 1937, the club  remains a central part of Galway‚Äôs sports culture. Now, with Ironland‚Äôs passionate support, Galway United is not just a team for Ireland‚Äîit‚Äôs become the heart of a historic collaboration that transcends borders.

To enter the giveaway of the signed copy of FC25, follow @GalwayUnitedFCTV  and leave a "For Ironland!" comment on their most recent video.

title: Is this country name accurate? ("M" Edition)
description:
The names of countries often carry deep historical, geographical, and cultural significance. However, over time, these meanings can become obscured due to translation, colonization, linguistic evolution, and cultural shifts. As a result, the original meanings may drift or be lost, leaving only a trace of the historical context embedded in the name.

Names like "Malaysia", "Malta",  and "Madagascar" each encapsulate unique stories of history, discovery, colonial influences in the intricate weave of cultures that name our world, leaving intriguing tales behind the names we use today.

title: The Gregorian Calendar Should Be Illegal
description:
Most of us follow the Gregorian calendar without giving it much thought: January, February, March... But have you ever wondered where those month names come from or why they even matter? The truth is, the names and structure we use today are pretty random. For example, "October" means "the eighth month," even though it‚Äôs now the tenth month on our calendar. So, is this really the best way to keep track of time?

Other cultures have come up with creative and practical ways to divide the year. For instance, the Natchez people of North America use 13 lunar cycles to mark their months, naming each one after something important for that time of year, like Deer Hunting Month or Strawberry Month. These names help people focus on what‚Äôs really happening in nature around them.

title: Why Do Re Mi is Wrong
description:
Solf√®ge, the familiar "do re mi fa so la ti do," is a system for teaching pitch and sight-singing. While many know it from music classes or the famous song in The Sound of Music, its origins are much older and more complex than they might appear.

Solf√®ge actually comes from a Latin hymn written in the 8th century called Ut Queant Laxis. The hymn was used to teach monks how to sight-read music, and each line of the hymn began with a different note. The first syllable of each line gave us the building blocks for solf√®ge: ‚ÄúUt, Re, Mi, Fa, So, La.‚Äù For example, "Ut" came from the first word of the hymn's opening line, "Ut queant laxis."

Originally, the system stopped at six syllables, ending with ‚ÄúLa,‚Äù and the first syllable was "Ut," not "Do." In the 1600s, Italian music theorist Giovanni Battista Doni suggested changing "Ut" to the more singable "Do." Later, in the 19th century, ‚ÄúTi‚Äù was added to complete the seven-note scale we use today.

The solf√®ge system, designed for teaching music and helping singers remember pitches, has evolved over time but remains a vital tool in music education.

title: 3 Phone Tips That Could Save Your Life
description:
When disaster strikes, staying connected can be a matter of life and death. But what happens if your cell phone loses service in the middle of a natural disaster like a hurricane or wildfire? Many of us rely on our phones for emergency calls, GPS, and keeping in touch with loved ones, but most don‚Äôt realize that a bit of preparation can make all the difference.

First, make sure your phone has the latest software update. Newer devices, like those running iOS 18 or the latest Android models, can access emergency satellite texting, even when regular networks are down. This means you don‚Äôt have to spend on expensive satellite internet to stay in touch.

Next, enable data roaming on your phone. This feature allows you to use other cellular networks when your primary carrier's service is disrupted. In a crisis, this could be your lifeline to critical information. Sometimes this feature is enabled automatically during a natural disaster, but during Hurricane Helene this system failed and the data roaming had to be enabled manually for many people. 

Lastly, know where your local Register of Deeds office is located. Often these offices have stable internet connections when everything else is down, making them a surprising but reliable spot to regain communication.

title: The Emergency in Asheville
description:
Last week, Hurricane Helene wreaked havoc across Asheville, North Carolina, and numerous other towns in the western part of the state. It ranks among the most devastating hurricanes in history, leaving large parts of the region unrecognizable. Thousands of people remain stranded in the mountains with no way out.

Entire communities have been cut off as floodwaters destroyed roads, homes, buildings, and vehicles. Communication infrastructure is in tatters, and millions have lost power and access to clean water across six states.

If you're wondering how to help, the best thing you can do is check on people living in and around Asheville by text. Ask if they need supplies, help with evacuation (there‚Äôs a severe gas shortage), or just share vital information since internet access is still severely limited.

For those living outside the area, the most effective way to assist is by donating to BeLoved Asheville (@belovedasheville6105). As a local resident, I know this organization has the infrastructure and knowledge to quickly deliver aid, especially to those often overlooked by larger organizations like FEMA and the Red Cross.

Paypal: BeLovedAsheville
Venmo: @BeLoved-Asheville

Official Asheville Account:@exploreasheville

title: Was Jesus Short?
description:
You‚Äôve probably heard the Bible story or song about Zacchaeus, the short tax collector who climbed a sycamore tree to see Jesus. But there may be a surprising twist to this familiar tale. The Gospel of Luke says that Zacchaeus ‚Äúcould not see Jesus because he was short in stature.‚Äù The question is: who is being described as short? Most assume it‚Äôs Zacchaeus, but the Greek text allows for a different interpretation‚Äîthat Jesus himself might have been short.

In his paper The Little Messiah, Dr. Isaac Soon argues that the Greek grammar suggests "he" refers to Jesus, not Zacchaeus. 

Adapted from a segment from the "Within Reason" podcast by @CosmicSkeptic  (Episode #72: Dr. John Nelson - What Did Jesus Really Look Like?)

title: Important Ironland Announcement
How People Used to Visualize Their Brains ü§Ø
description:
Throughout history, metaphors for the brain have shifted alongside technological and cultural advances. Today, we often compare the brain to a computer, thinking of it as a processing system for information. However, before the computer, people used other metaphors to explain how the brain worked. In the 17th century, influenced by developments in physics, thinkers like Ren√© Descartes described the brain as pneumatic or hydraulic. They imagined fluids traveling through tubes and valves, much like water flowing through pumps. This mirrored the mechanical technologies of the time.

Going further back, in the Middle Ages, the brain was sometimes seen as a mystical organ responsible for balancing the humors‚Äîsubstances that supposedly governed health and temperament. Ancient Greek scholars like Aristotle didn't even believe the brain was involved in thinking. They thought it served a much more basic function: cooling the body. For Aristotle, the heart was the seat of thought and emotion, with the brain acting like a radiator for excess heat.

Each metaphor reflects the tools and understanding available at the time, from primitive cooling systems to complex computer networks today.

title: Why You Can't Actually Own Land In America
description:
Allodial title refers to the concept of owning property outright, free from obligations like taxes or external claims. In the U.S., while property owners hold a deed and may feel like they truly own their land, the reality is more complex due to eminent domain. Under eminent domain, the government retains the right to take private property for public use, as long as they provide fair compensation. This power highlights that property ownership in the U.S. isn‚Äôt absolute.

Eminent domain is a key distinction between modern property ownership and allodial title. In an allodial system, ownership is unconditional‚Äîthere are no taxes, duties, or threats of seizure, even by the government.  Allodial title has existed during a few periods of history, such as after the French Revolution, when allodial title emerged as a rejection of the old feudal system, granting people complete control over their land. Although France no longer operates under this system, some Viking-influenced regions like Orkney, Shetland, and the Isle of Man may still have remnants of allodial title today.

title: Who Has 1,000 Things Named After Them?
description:
Eponyms are words or names derived from a person, often honoring their contributions to science, culture, or exploration. Some individuals accumulate multiple eponyms, like Sequoyah, with trees, a national forest, and a car named after him. However, few people match the sheer volume of eponyms attached to the 19th-century German explorer and naturalist Alexander von Humboldt, who holds the record by a significant margin.

Humboldt's success in amassing eponyms is largely due to his privileged background and timing. Born into a wealthy family in 1769, he had the resources and connections to fund extensive scientific expeditions at a time when global exploration was just becoming feasible for private individuals. His groundbreaking work in geography, biology, and environmental science not only earned him international fame but also resulted in over 1,000 things named after him‚Äîincluding 100 animals, 300 plants, mountains, glaciers, and even a section of the moon. 

This mix of social privilege, access to cutting-edge exploration, and a world fascinated by discovery allowed Humboldt to carve out a legacy that has lasted centuries. Today, he remains the individual with the most eponyms by a large margin, embodying the impact of exploration and scientific achievement.

title: The Oldest Nation in the World?
description:
France is often considered the first modern nation in history due to its early development of national identity, centralized government, and defined borders. While other empires and kingdoms existed before, France was one of the first to establish the key elements that would come to define a modern nation-state.

While great civilizations like Rome, Egypt, and China built vast empires, they didn‚Äôt foster the kind of unified national identity or governance we associate with modern nations today. These empires were collections of diverse peoples, often ruled through local authorities and distant, imperial oversight.

title: The Fish That Changed The World
description:
Salt cod, a staple of maritime trade for centuries, has had a profound impact on global history over the past millennium. By the 9th century, Vikings were salting and drying cod to preserve it for long voyages, enabling exploration across the North Atlantic. As European fishing fleets expanded in the 15th and 16th centuries, salt cod became a key commodity, especially for countries like Portugal, Spain, and England, whose sailors relied on this durable protein source during long expeditions.

The discovery of vast cod-rich waters off Newfoundland in the early 1500s fueled international competition, driving both European colonization of the Americas and the growth of transatlantic trade routes. Salt cod also played a role in the triangular trade, where it was exchanged for slaves in Africa, who were then sent to the Caribbean, and sugar shipped back to Europe.

Its influence spread into culinary traditions as well, from bacalhau in Portugal to brandade in France. Salt cod's global reach allowed it to serve as a unifying foodstuff across diverse cultures. By providing sustenance for explorers, sailors, and entire communities, salt cod became a cornerstone of economic and social developments in the Atlantic world, shaping history for over a thousand years.

title: The Ironland Embassy Awards
description:
We have reached a milestone that‚Äôs nothing short of extraordinary! With embassies in nearly 50 countries around the world, Ironland is more connected and celebrated than ever before. 

To honor the creativity and dedication of our ambassadors, we're inviting YOU, the proud citizens of Ironland, to cast your vote in four exciting categories. This is your chance to have a say in recognizing our favorite embassies and celebrating the global presence we‚Äôve built together. üåç

title: Each President's Favorite Movie
description:
Woodrow Wilson holds the distinction of being the first U.S. president to watch a feature film while in office. The movie, The Birth of a Nation, premiered in 1915 and was shown in a private screening at the White House. This event marked the beginning of a longstanding tradition where a president's taste in movies might offer a glimpse into their personality and values.

Over the years, the movies that presidents favor have often reflected their personal experiences, ideals, and even the era in which they served. For example, Harry Truman, who led the country through the final stages of World War II and the beginning of the Cold War, was a fan of Westerns. These films, often centered on themes of justice, resilience, and the American frontier spirit, resonated with Truman's no-nonsense, straightforward approach to leadership.

Ronald Reagan, a former actor turned president, had a soft spot for The Sound of Music.

These cinematic preferences offer more than just a peek into a president's leisure activities‚Äîthey provide a unique lens through which we can understand the men behind the office.

title: The Person With The Most Citizenships
description:
Holding multiple citizenships means being a legal citizen of more than one country simultaneously. This can happen through birth, where a person inherits citizenship from parents of different countries or from the country where they were born. Some people gain additional citizenships through naturalization after meeting residency requirements.

In recent years, wealthy individuals have found ways to buy citizenship in certain countries, usually by investing large sums of money. This can offer benefits like visa-free travel, tax advantages, and a backup plan if they need to relocate.

On the other hand, geopolitical situations can also leave people with multiple citizenships. For instance, people in regions with shifting borders or historical conflicts might find themselves eligible for citizenship in multiple countries. A notable example is a group with Chinese heritage in Timor Leste who ended up eligible for five citizenships due to the island‚Äôs complex history.

title: This Loophole Lets Two Nations Share Land
description:
In international law, a "condominium" refers to a piece of territory that is jointly owned and administered by two or more sovereign states. Unlike a condominium in real estate, where individuals own units within a larger property, an international condominium is a form of shared sovereignty. The countries involved share equal rights and responsibilities over the territory, and decisions regarding its governance are typically made collectively.

Historically, international condominiums have been rare, but they have existed in various forms. One example is the condominium of the Sudan, which was jointly administered by the United Kingdom and Egypt from 1899 until Sudan's independence in 1956. Another example is the New Hebrides, now known as Vanuatu, which was jointly administered by France and the United Kingdom until its independence in 1980.

These arrangements often arise from historical treaties or agreements, and the specific terms of governance and sovereignty can vary widely depending on the nature of the condominium.

title: The Vice Presidents That America Forgot
description:
The role of Vice President of the United States is one of the most unusual in American politics. Despite being just a heartbeat away from the presidency, vice presidents often fade into obscurity, their names and contributions largely forgotten. 

What‚Äôs even more surprising is how often the vice presidency has been left vacant. In the 19th century, when a vice president died in office, there was no system in place to appoint a replacement. As a result, the position was left empty for long stretches of time‚Äîsometimes for years. During these periods, the nation operated without a vice president.

The history of the vice presidency is a reminder of how even crucial political roles can evolve and how their significance can change over time.

title: Why The Olympics Aren't Fair
description:
The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has long been criticized for its Western Europe-centric orientation, a bias that influences the selection of sports offered in the Olympics.
